Award.AwardTitle: Social Influences on Reproductive Decisions- revised
Award.AbstractNarration: The social environment can influence the individual in many different ways. Social factors can affect learning, development and even health. The focus of this proposal is to examine how different types of social environments can impact the health of parents and offspring. The model system under study is the brown-headed cowbird. Cowbirds are an excellent model for investigating the influence of social environments on health because, being obligate brood parasites, they engage in no parental care, thus the viability of their young is not confounded by parental abilities. This project is designed to take an integrative approach in examining the function and cause of social influences on mating, reproductive success, and health of parents and offspring. It combines observational studies of large groups of birds with proximate measures of circulating hormone actions. Captive flocks of cowbirds will be observed and experimentally manipulated (by changing the social composition of the flocks, and with hormone implants). This procedure provides (1) control over the social experiences the birds gain, (2) measures of reproductive success, and (3), measures of the growth and vigor of the young. This work has the promise to advance knowledge on where and when selection may act on flexible behavior patterns in social organisms and to reveal the strength of cultural processes influencing health and viability. In addition, the lab has a strong educational mission; it is attractive to broad range of students including underrepresented groups. Finally, cowbirds are a species of concern due to their ability to reproduce at high rates. This work has the potential to provide new knowledge about the factors that stimulate female reproduction that could be used for management and conservation programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this work has been on investigating how the social environment can influence the development of effective behaviour and influence reproductive decision making. I study brown-headed cowbirds as a model species of sociality. There are few other systems that provide a tractable experimental preparation that captures the full range of neural, physiological and behavioral processes that mediate the complex interplay among individuals in social groups. By studying captive flocks in large outdoor aviaries, I am able to experimentally manipulate individuals in groups and thus can examine the causal and functional links between brain, behaviour, and sociality.

 

 The most exciting findings resulting from this grant derived from a collaboration with Marc Schmidt in Biology at Penn. We have been able to show that targeted lesions to the song control system in female cowbirds can have large, widespread effects on their reproductive decisions, and also on the behavior of the social network surrounding the females. By placing lesioned females in large breeding groups of other cowbirds we have documented effects on male aggression, female competition, and pairbonding. Furthermore, through studies of the females’ preferences for male courtship song, we found that these lesions made the females unselective in their attitudes toward different songs. Most recently, we found that females with these lesions lay on average 4 times as many eggs as females without lesions.  Taken together, the work is starting to reveal how females’ song preferences play a role in regulating their social group, their behavior, and their reproductive physiology.  

 

In a second experiment, we have been able to document that females maintain or dissolve pairbonds based on their reproductive output the year before. We found that females are more likely to divorce males with whom they produced fewer than average eggs. Moreover, when we investigated their song preferences, females who had laid more than average eggs with a particular male subsequently gained an enhanced preference for that male's song (this enhanced preference did not exist for the females who divorced their mates). The pairbonding experiment has provided a first demonstration of how the reproductive success of a pairbond can influence females' sexual preferences.

 

My lab involves a large number of students and as such provides numerous opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science. I am intent on providing access now and in the future to members of underrepresented groups. I provide public outreach tours of my lab and presentations as a way to encourage members of the public to become interested in science.
